item.description:
Mountain Pass Chess uses all sixteen chess pieces per side, but they are used on a 5 square X 7 square board, with three pawns, one bishop, one knight and one rook held in reserve to be brought in on the first row as space is available. Chess rules apply with some exceptions: Castling is allowed but only on the King side; the placement of a reserve piece to a first row space constitutes a move, and an opponents piece can be captured if it happens to occupy that space; as in Backgammon, a doubling cube can be used for side wagers, but is not necessary for playing the game;

From the box: MOUNTAIN PASS CHESS has been discribed as incorporating the most revolutionary change in the rules for regular chess since the change that allowed castling. The game provides the opportunity for new study in openings, middle game and end game pley. As stated on the cover of this box...
THE ULTIMATE CHESS CHALLENGE."

ClaudeSoucie is a variant on Lines of Action, where the object is to be the first player to get all their pieces into one group. ClaudeSoucie differs from Lines of Action several different ways:
1. The game is played is playable on a 10x10 board, or larger or smaller size.
2. One player sets up all the pieces around the outside of the board, and the other player then picks what color they will play.
3. Pieces that would normally be removed from play are put at the bottom of the piece that is capturing the piece in the stack. By doing this, a capture creates a stack of pieces containing 2 or more pieces. A single piece can move on top of a stack of pieces to control the entire stack.
4. The player who is the first player to have all their pieces in one group at the start of their turn wins, as opposed to immediately, as is the case with Lines of Action.

ClaudeSoucie was invented by Donald Silberger.

item.description: This is an educational card game for teaching materials science to people. This game can be played by 2 or more players. Shuffle the cards and deal them face down. Each player turn the top card face up but in a way that others don't see the card. Each card present a material with 6 attributes. The player to the left of the dealer picks one attribute from the top card and reads its number, eg. density 2320. Other players read out their respective attribute. The highest value on the attribute collects all other top cards and place them in their pile. Then it's the winner's turn to turn the top card and to pick an attribute. In the case of a tie in the attribute value, these cards are placed in the centre of the table and the main player gets to pick another card and to choose an attribute. The winner gets to take the cards from both rounds.

Quarq is a card game system. You can play an unlimited number of games with a Deck of Quarqs.

Quarq games are simple. The rules for each fit on a single card.

Fundamentally, Quarq is a deck of 72 cards, consisting of

 60 Quarq cards, each a unique "3-D" combination of 3 of the 12 suits
 12 suit cards, which are used in some games




Quarq comes packaged with 14 games, including

 5 adaptations of top traditional card games
 4 brand new strategy card games
 3 novel stand-up games
 2 poker games




...and many more Quarq games added by YOU, the community, at quarq.org.

Quarq games range from 
twists on traditional games like Bridge, Hearts, Concentration, to
radically new games that could not be played with a traditional deck of cards, like Psychics, Trade Routes, Conquistaspores. Some are designed for 2 young kids; others are for 15 abstract thinkers.

Quarq games are more radically diverse than traditional card games. They use almost any other mechanic.

As it is a game system, Quarq is also a creative medium. 
At quarq.org, players can create new games, or post reviews of existing Quarq games. They earn points for their participation.

From the publisher's website:
""The Romans knew not…how deeply the greatness of their own prosperity and the fate of the whole Western world were involved in the destruction of the fleet of Athens in the harbor of Syracuse.” Arnold

Say what? The ‘fate of the whole Western world?’ Syracuse? How?

Simple. If the Athenians had taken Syracuse, during their invasion of 415 BCE, they would have captured Sicily and become a major superpower. They would dominate the Italian boot as well, and make it much harder for a city-state named Rome to expand.

Maybe one of the oddest things about the lengthy Peloponnesian War is that, after decades of balance, the Athenians actually lost it with a campaign well away from the Greek mainland.

The Athenians have a mighty host of fleets and men, filled with confidence. The Syracusans have a long history of clinging to their independence (and powerful allies coming to foil Athens).

Combat units include cavalry, light troops, peltasts, and the heavily armed hoplites—the backbone of both sides’ armies. You the players can decide your best approaches for attack and defense, selecting from pitched battles or skirmishes…or building miles of siege walls.

The Siege of Syracuse includes:
One full color, 11” x 17” mounted mapboard
One 8.5” x 11” battle board
176 large, full color, die-cut counters
12 page rulebook

Can you extend the Golden Age of Athens or maintain the freedom of the most powerful city in the mid Mediterranean?

Part of the TPS "Decisive Battles" series

That means straightforward rules, key insights into the history behind the game, and designs aimed at one-session conclusions and high replay value. "

name.value: The Battle of The Metaurus Northern Italy 207 BC

item.description:
From the publisher's website:
"As people think over the actions of Hannibal in the 2nd Punic War, many great battles come to mind…Cannae, Zama, Trebia, Lake Trasimene…

Yet, Creasy chose The Metaurus as the decisive battle for the entire war. How can that be? Hannibal was not even there!

But his brother was there, in command of an army sent to reinforce Hannibal and give him the strength and stamina to finish off the Romans. By this time (207 BCE), the Romans were mostly avoiding head-to-head battles with Hannibal, and he mostly lacked the cavalry strength to force them to fight where he wanted them to. When the Romans intercepted messengers Hasdrubal sent to alert Hannibal to his arrival, they realized how critical it was to keep the brothers from joining together, and rushed an overwhelming force to surprise and destroy the new army. And won.

Now, see if you can change or maintain the history.

The Romans have numbers and overall troop quality on their side. Hasdrubal has a wide range of troops, from crack heavy infantry and light cavalry from Africa to poor quality Celtic levies. And, they have the superior position. The game calls on both players to “do better” than their historical counterparts. Richard Berg’s design emphasizes morale and the importance of getting troops to execute the right commands.
The Battle of the Metaurus includes:
One 11” x 17” mounted game-map
200 die-cut mounted counters
8 page Rules Booklet

Part of the TPS "Decisive Battles" series

That means straightforward rules, key insights into the history behind the game, and designs aimed at one-session conclusions and high replay value. "

Chung Ling Soo was a very talented stage magician who was shot and killed during last nights performance. You play a police detective who will try to bring in more evidence than the other players. The game board is made up of 12 hex tiles which make up a map of London. You may move your pawns around a maze of streets, back alleys and even make use of the Underground train system. The three interior tiles have police stations, the nine outside tiles have evidence locations. The object of this game is to score the most victory points. Victory points are earned by moving your "police" pawn around the game board to various named evidence locations, acquiring the evidence and returning the evidence to one of three police stations. When you attempt to find the piece of evidence you decide how valuable it will be, the more valuable the harder it is to find. During your game turn you also move one of nine "bad" guy pawns. When moved adjacent to another players pawn you may pay the "bad" guy to attempt to steal various items from the player (money, tools, or evidence). The game ends when evidence from all differently named nine evidence tiles have been turned in by any combination of players.

NooPolitik is a non-collectable table- top card game designed by Ben Drain and published through the print-on-demand site thegamecrafter.com . 
Players take on the role of one of 12 countries attempting to make a mark on history. As such, the theme of the game is historical and political. Players interact with each other through the spheres of political, military, clandestine, and economic pools of resources, using 3 different bidding systems. When a player accomplishes a feat such as bringing a new achievement into the world, or expunging someone else’s, they score a card towards victory, playing to 21 points.
The game contains 12 unique country cards, 96 unique action cards, 104 unique achievements, 18 multicolored non-standard dice, and a large collection of resource tokens representing the resources of the game (labor, steel, plastics, unrest, etc), and 50 glass beads used for bidding.

item.description: "Show me a good loser, and I'll show you a real loser." Oneupmanship is a satirical board game where the players struggle for money, power, and ego. The winner is the first player to earn $100,000 through any means possible: playing the stock market, building skyscrapers, gambling, or collecting trophies.

item.description:
You are a cunning and dastardly spy. Deny it, you scoundrel! Use your skills of wit and observation to discover the other spies’ identities and expose them before they expose you. The winner is the last remaining spy.

Logical Spies unfolds like a social logic puzzle, in which the players play the role of a spy. Your identity is represented by 6 cards: Nationality, Codename, Cover, Vulnerability, Secret Weapon, and special Agent ability.

Each round begins with the Spying phase and ends with the Accusations phase. Spying is fast and simultaneous. Recover your cards as quickly as you can while observing what other players do. Accusations is calculating and methodical. Consult your Logic Sheet. Accuse other players until you make a false accusation. As you make correct accusations, players must reveal that card.
When your entire identity is revealed, you are out of the game.

The 12 Agent cards add a special ability. The Enigma may lie about his Codename. The Assassin may wink at players to make them reveal a card. The Die Hard gets 1 final round of accusations upon elimination...

(From the publisher's web site) Of all the battles in the American Revolution, Saratoga was the one that really gave the Patriots a belief that they could win—and convinced the outside world (starting with France) that the rebels were worth supporting. Take away the victory at Saratoga, and we can only wonder how much more time would have passed before the French alliance happened…if ever.

Now you can explore the two main battles of Saratoga, both Freeman’s Farm and Bemis Heights, as a growing storm of colonial militia and regulars, commanded by Gates but really led by Arnold, turned “Gentleman Johnny’s” adventure into a disaster.

Rob Markham’s design gives life to the combatants, as players wrestle with command-control, fog-of-war, and troop quality ratings that mean a larger force may actually be weaker.
The Battle of Saratoga contains:
One 11” by 17” mounted map sheet
One set of 200 die cut mounted counters
One 8 page rulebook
Two Six-Sided Dice

Available for free on the IronWall Games website.

Viking Funeral makes use of decks of standard playing cards that would otherwise be disposed of. Like "Risk: Legacy" by the same designer, permanent changes are made to the cards throughout the course of play, and these changes will persist into future plays of the game using the same set of cards.

This game is played with a 52-card deck (French-suited) that you supply yourself, and a marker or pen to write on the cards, and optionally, a pair of scissors or matches or something to destroy cards with, and if available, a trash can to serve as "Valhalla".

A single card is drawn randomly at the start of a game and destroyed, but not to the point of its number and suit being unrecognizable. This becomes the "recently deceased".

Players start with a hand of cards, with the lead player playing a single card to the center of the table ("the funeral") that are either in agreement (same suit color) or start a fight (differing suit colors).

Tricks are won by playing the high card when in agreement, or by winning fights (being form the same family as the recently deceased provides a bonus in a fight). The winner takes the trick and puts the cards into that player's victory point pile ("mead hall"). Cards are drawn by the player who did not win cards for their mead hall from the deck ("the village").

Throughout play, players are encouraged to either sing the praises of the "recently deceased" or trash-talk the card, treating each suit as it were an viking family line. The game ends when no more cards are left in the village to replenish players' hands, and the game is won by the player with the most cards in their mead hall, with a tie breaker going to the player whose mead hall cards have the most wounds (as indicated by marks made to cards during play).

In true viking fashion, the game strongly emphasis that there are no ties, either during play or in calculating victory.

Sparta versus Athens is a strategic level game of the Peloponnesian War in it's entirety, spanning twenty-eight years, from 431 B.C. to 404 B.C. The map is a point-to-point map, using city-states and the common land and navigable sea routes as the conduits that defined the Grecian Mediterranean. The game is designed for simple movement and combat mechanics to resolve battles and sieges, all centered upon the predominance of famous and historic leaders (e.g., Alcibiades). The game is richly historic, and keeps players within historic parameters in such a way that alliances and politics can shift, depending on how the war is going, but only within the limits of historic possibilities. Some city-states of the Delos Confederation may ally with Athens, while others may ally with Sparta, for example. Athens vs Sparta includes four scenarios: The Archidamian War (431 - 422), The Peace of Nicias and the Sicilian Expedition (421 – 413), The Ionian War (412 – 404), and the campaign scenario covering the entire war.

The game includes one 22x34" map of the Grecian Mediterranean, including Sicily and southern Italy, and as far east as the Persian empire, 280 counters of all participants in the Peloponnesian War. Each game turn is played as four seasons of one year. Each inch equals ~18 miles. One naval strength point represents 5 galleys of the era (Triremes), and one land strength point represents 350 to 450 heavy infantry (Hoplites) or 500 to 600 light infantry or 200 to 300 cavalry.

Components: One 22" x 34" map & 280 counters.

item.description:
A Fantasy Island-Building Game for 2 - 4 Tribal Leaders by Andreas Propst & Tobias Strunz.

“In the middle of a medieval fantasy archipelago, rival tribes are building their settlements on neighbouring islands. You are the clan-chief of one of these tribes and responsible for your village. Build and expand your settlement, care for your followers and nurture your clan. Finally you will be able to build a massive army or achieve cultural superiority. Whatever path to victory you choose - the fantasy islands await you!”

The goal of the game is to be the first player to collect 20 Victory Points. Each player starts with a tiny Starting Island made out of 7 hex tiles. Players will expand their islands in order to mine stone, ore and gather wood needed to build the more advanced buildings. Players will grow food and wine to keep their soldiers and wizards loyal and collect mana to cast powerful Spells.

In Fantasy Islands, many roads lead to victory: Pure Military force, Naval supremacy, securing the Trade monopoly, keeping your population happy, Cultural dominance or Spellcasting power. Excelling at one or more of these aspects will net you the VP needed to win and furthermore, players will be able to engage in Conflicts (Military, Trade, Sorcery, Cultural and Naval) which, in case they emerge victorious, will get them certain benefits.

This game is a cooperative effort by Andreas Propst (Austria) and Tobias Strunz (Germany).

Hatfield vs. McCoy - "Gold Rush" is a dice / strategy table top game of hillbilly prospecting. Each family is seeking new gold mine claims. Roll your dice to pick up new claims, or become a claim jumper and try to take one from the other family. Roll your 5 rock, paper, scissors dice and bid them against a family member that holds that mine. The family with the most claims that hit gold at the end of the game wins!

This Box Contains: 
5 Custom RPS Blue Dice
5 Custom RPS Red Dice
2 Custom Black Dice
8 Red Marker Pawns
8 Blue Marker Pawns
12 Prospecting Cards
3 Hatfield Family Cards
3 McCoy Family Cards
2 Game Guide Cards
And 1 Rule Book

In the two-player game Four Tribes, each player takes on the role of a powerful monarch in conflict with the other during a time of famine. The war is at a stalemate, and both leaders decide that the key to destroying the other is to recruit the help of the Northern Tribes! Each player attempts to sway the Village Elders of the Four Tribes to join their cause by supplying each village with desperately needed supplies. Win the village, and you gain the favor of the Village Elder! Gain the favor of enough Village Elders, and you will win the support of the Four Tribes and be victorious!

While Four Tribes is a two-player game, a four-player variant will be part of the finished product.

User Description

A set of simple fast play wargame rules designed for fighting large scale battles using 6mm and 2mm scale miniatures. They cover the period from 1935 to the present day.

They also have WWII army lists, supplement rules for post 1945 and air to ground aircraft rules.

They have been designed to use a D6 dice and minitures which are multiable based in to units (dependent on scale).
A spin and move game where you are trying to shoot the most valuable big game animals using a spinner shaped lie a gun.

Retro Rampage Trivia Quest is a table top trivia game focusing on classic games and consoles, ranging from the Nintendo Entertainment System and Sega Master System, up until the Super Nintendo, Sega Genesis, and even the Turbografx-16 and the PC Engine.

item.description:
Using American Football fundamentals, players simulate an Iowa Hawkeye football game with charts, dice, and an exact replica Kinnick Field game board.

Game-Play: The defensive player secretly selects one of three defensive formations (running, blitzing, and passing) and marks it with his d6. Then, the offensive player verbally selects one of tweleve running or passing plays. The defensive player exposes his formation, and the offensive player rolls 2d10 to reveal the outcome of the play from the play chart. Play results include, but are not limited to: incomplete pass, interception, sack, penalty, touchdown, no gain, or a yardage gain of another dice roll. Game time and score are tracked on a separate charts. Special team results are also covered on a field goal, kick-off, and punt chart.

Contents: 2 play charts, 1 exact replica of Kinnick Field game board, 1 field goal and penalty chart, 1 official time chart, scorepad, 1 line-of-scrimmage marker, 1 ten-yard marker, 3 colored markers, 2 offensive dice (d10), 1 defensive die (d6), 1 rules folder, and 1 Hawkeye button (1st issue Collectors Edition only).

The game rules do not cover the sport of American Football; therefore, basic knowledge of the sport should be known or referenced with a NCAA college football handbook.

Boardgame "U Koryta" is a satire of political and social issues, the realities of the political fictional world, localized somewhere between the fall of the Fourth Republic and the birth of Fifth Republic. 
Players take the role of gray eminences. They leads political parties and their choices affect both the shape the political scene, but also the condition of the state.

http://www.bellringer.pl/u-koryta,3.html

item.description:
The goal of Galtoni is to connect 4 balls in a straight (diagonal or orthogonal) line. Unlike in other games with this concept, however, there is a randomizer involved, as the game is played on a type of Galton box. Players take turns inserting a ball in one of the openings at the top of the slanted board. It hits a series of pins which deflect it, before falling into one of seven slots at the bottom. The first player who manages to form a straight line of four balls in his/her color is the winner.
There are two neutral balls included as well, which both players can use for their lines. 
In a variant, the balls are randomly drawn from a bag, so a players sometimes insert balls that belong to the other player, trying to put it into a useless position.

This edition of the Trivial Pursuit game is dedicated to the history of F.C. Barcelona (Barça).

The mechanics of the game aer similar to the other Trivial Pursuit games, with questions about players, games , history and other sports sections of F.C. Barcelona.

Once upon a time, there was an old kingdom, where executives manipulated complicated relationships in order to gain fame and fortune. The players are these executives; the goal of the game earning as much influence in the royal palace as possible, all the while downing the rivals.

Character cards are lined up in a 3 x 4 grid. Players take turns gaining one of these cards each, combined with a so-called "mission disc". After each player has taken a card, discs and possibly cards are refilled, and the next player chooses a card to take. When the round is finished, players earn points for the discs of the colours of which he has the most influence, and penalty points for certain others.

Game goes on for two rounds, and the player with the most points at the end wins.

(from GMT website:)

Volume IV in GMT’s COIN Series dives headlong into the momentous and complex battle for South Vietnam. A unique multi-faction treatment of the Vietnam War, Fire in the Lake will take 1 to 4 players on US heliborne sweeps of the jungle and Communist infiltration of the South, and into inter-allied conferences, Saigon politics, interdiction of the Ho Chi Minh Trail, air defense of Northern infrastructure, graduated escalation, and media war.

Renowned designer and modern warfare expert Mark Herman joins COIN Series creator Volko Ruhnke for a collaborative production not to be missed. Fire in the Lake features the same card-assisted counterinsurgency game system as GMT's Andean Abyss, Cuba Libre, and A Distant Plain, with a pack of twists that take the Series to another level, including:


 Pivotal events that trump initiative (Tet Offensive, Vietnamization, Easter Offensive, and Linebacker II)
 Inter-coup campaign effects that vary by RVN leader
 Counterinsurgent guerrillas (US-led Irregulars and ARVN Rangers)
 Insurgent troops (NVA) for direct force-on-force engagements
 Tunneled VC and NVA bases
 Trail construction and degradation
 A larger-than-ever event deck for even greater play variety
 Short and medium-length scenarios with either random or period-event options


DESIGNER: Mark Herman & Volko Ruhnke
SERIES DEVELOPER: Mike Bertucelli
MAP ART: Chechu Nieto
COUNTER & CARDS ART & RULES LAYOUT: Mark Simonitch

item.description:
This is a math based card game. The object of the game is to play eight cards, each with a larger number, in a sequence. There are eight different sequences each starting from a number between one and eight. The sequence is basically the multiplication table. For example, the second number in the sequence that starts with 5 is 10 and the third number in that sequence is 15. You do not have to stay in the same sequence. If you have played a 10, you can proceed with a 12 or 15. The cards helpfully show which cards they can be played on and which cards can be played on them.

Each of up to four players is dealt three cards. On each turn they can draw a card from the draw pile or the discard pile. They then either place a card in their sequence or discard. There are eight cards when played cause player to exchange hands.

Scoring is done by adding up all the points played by the player who completes his sequence of eight cards. All the other players add up their cards played and subtract the points for cards still held in their hand.

name.value: Polite Pigs Playing Cards: A Game of Good Manners

item.description:
From the game itself:

"Polite Pigs will familiarize children with the etiquette of responding appropriately in a variety of social situations. It is also designed to reinforce and habituate these responses through verbal repetition. Parents should enjoy hearing their children repeatedly ask and give permission to proceed as the game is played. The object of the game is to capture the most situation cards with the appropriate polite responses."

Gameplay description:

Cards are dealt to each player (child). The remaining cards form a draw pile. The dealer turns cards over from the draw pile until s/he reaches a "situation" card. (Others are mixed back into the pile.)

The dealer announces the situation and the youngest player (presumably to help children learn politeness and pragmatics starting at a young age) figures out whether s/he has the appropriate response card. If so, s/he says so and takes the situation card as a matched pair with his/her response card.

Else, the player takes a draw card and further, the game's rules require the child state, "Now you try, please" and the next player or opponent to respond, "Thank you" as an additional method of reinforcing politeness. If the next player has the corresponding response card, s/he may claim the pair. Otherwise, s/he draws a card and play continues so on and so forth.

If a player is able to match a response card to a situation card, s/he become dealer. A series of formalistic polite exchanges must be had between the players and if any player forgets the appropriate phrase, such as, "May I give you a situation, please?" then the offending player must hand his opponent a response card or draw until he gets one to hand over.

The winner is the one with the most pairs.

Ultimately, this game focuses not only on physical game mechanics but social dynamics to reinforce its educational affect. The rules take into account that the players may fail to say required phrases, something akin to—but more complex than—the requirement in UNO to declare "¡Uno!" with one card left in hand.

Based on the Classic & Original Jenga Game

Keep your tower from toppling! Set up your tower of multicolored blocks—each color counts for a different point. Then, aim your blaster at the tower to try to knock a block off. Just aim carefully, because you don’t want the tower to fall! See if you can even manage the ultimate trick shot: blast out the last block in a level to drop the top blocks down!
Includes JENGA blaster, 39 foam blocks, pedestal, 13 crash chips and rules.

name.value: Seasons of War: Days of the Conqueror

item.description:
Days of the Conqueror is a mass-battle miniatures game for the period of William the Conqueror (11th century). Units are composed of a number of stands of miniatures. Units are rated by a die (D4, D6, D8, or D10) in each attribute: Discipline, Morale, Attack, and Armor.

Each unit must make a Discipline Test (with results of either Rash, Simple, or Strategic) each turn to determine what action it can or must perform. Rash actions require units to make disadvantageous actions, while Strategic actions allow more complex actions such as reforming, force marching, and forming shieldwall.

The combat system is very "Risk-like" where the Armor dice of the defender are compared to the Attack (or missile) dice of the attacker, with each Attacking die that exceeds an Armor die causing a hit. Units use their Morale attribute whenever they take damage to determine their reaction.

Army lists for Normans, Anglo-Saxons, Vikings, Franks, Bretons are included. Six typical scenarios are included as well as a campaign system that links the scenarios.

This is an educational game. You are rolling dices to move around the board - depending on the field you stay on - you earn some cards (you can use them against your oponent or to defense yourself) or get questions (correct answer give you positive points). The goal is to score as many points.

link.value: Once Upon a Time (based on animated series)

item.description:
Blocky Mountains is a dexterity game playable with 2-7 players in either a cooperative or with 2-4 players in a competitive manner or as a solo game. The core of the game consists of 3D landscapes that you build with large wooden blocks, after which you try to maneuver a large wooden pawn ("the trapper") over this course.

In competitive play, you want to be the first to reach the mountain summit on the score track ("the route map"), and to do so you must master several challenges. Each challenge consists of a parcours built out of the wooden blocks according to the challenge card you draw randomly from three piles: A - C, from easy to difficult. After having built the landscape course, you have to push, pull, lift, slide or swing the "trapper" from the start to the end block. This trapper has a metal eye on top, and you move it with a wooden rod with a hook at its end. Some challenges require an intermediate string between rod and pawn, while others require both hands to simultaneously move pawn and grizzly bear, the bear being another wooden piece. A third kind of piece to be moved is provisions, which you "kick" with the trapper.

When you master the challenge, the next player decides whether to change to the next parcours or try to master the same one again. Depending on the difficulty of the challenge, your piece can move 2-4 steps toward the summit. If you lose track, fall down, or lose your provisions, you have lost this challenge and must move backward! The game includes other details – e.g., owls and squirrel tokens for managing your skills and special actions – but this is more or less the whole game.

item.description:
2 players, X and O

Materials
A sheet with an 8×8 board missing its four corners and subdivided into tetromino-shaped spaces

2 pencils

Adjacent - Means orthogonally or diagonally adjacent.

Objective
Make a straight line of five adjacent marks to win.

Play
The board starts out empty.

Choose a start player in any convenient manner, turns then alternate.

Player one on his first turn draws one of his marks in an empty space on the board.

Hereafter players draw two of their marks per turn into empty spaces on the board.

No two players marks may be drawn into adjacent empty spaces unless they are part of a single tetromino shape.

If after making 2 of your marks you’ve filled in a tetromino shape, you get to draw another mark. If that 3rd mark fills in another shape you get to place a 4th, etc. then your turn ends.

item.description:
FUBA is a tactical football simulation. This smart, fast-paced game takes on the world's number one sport from a tactical view. In FUBA, you become the head coach and choose the strategy for your team. Control the midfield with 4-5-1? Use two strikers to secure the win with 4-4-2? The choice is yours.

The game is resolved in less than an hour, which is quicker than a real match. FUBA is played in turns, with an average of 23 turns per each half. The player controlling the ball chooses the action his team will go for, then both players roll the dice to see the outcome. After this, both players move their team according to the tactics they have chosen. There is always a small chance of random events such as a yellow or red card.

Thanks to the flexible rubber board, FUBA can easily be played outdoors, too.

item.description:
Conquer the largest number of islands of the archipelago of the Azores.
The player who answers correctly two questions about the Azores, can choose which island is conquered.

Bilingual: English/Portuguese

Roll the dice and move player pawns through the archipelago the required number of spaces in any direction and answer the appropriate question based on where you land. If correct take over an island and roll again.

Object: take over as much of the Azores as you can.

Swytch, the second in the BGO series by designer Nathan Hansen, is a symmetrically balanced abstract strategy game for 2 players. Each player has two types of Counters: Hexagonal and Circular. Hexagonal counters can move in 3 directions, while Circular counters can move in all 6 directions.

Each player tries to outmaneuver and eliminate all of the opposing player's pieces on the board. To do this, they can do one of three things on their turn. They can either: Move/Attack with a counter or stack of counters, prepare a stack of Hexagonal counters for an advanced move with changing directions, or "Swytch" (i.e., change the orientation of a Stack of Hexagonal counters, and thus what directions they can move). Every time that a player attacks with a stack of counters, they MUST also Swytch with that stack immediately after.

The number of spaces a stack of counters can move/attack is determined by its height. When a player attacks by moving into an opponents stack, they reduce the size of the target's stack of counters by the size of their own. If this is enough to eliminate the target, they do so. If not, they are forced to stop one space short and also reduce the size of their stack by 1.

Deeply strategic and full of possibilities, get the upper hand in Swytch!

Game Data:

Complexity: 5 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 2 on a 9 scale

Polybag Game Components:

• One 8-page full-color Rules booklet 
• One 8.5” x 11” game map
• 52 two-sided, multi-shaped game pieces

item.description:
Snacks and Bladders teaches anatomy, biology, diet & nutrition by exploring the human digestive system through roll & move and trivia question mechanics.

Correctly identify body parts and make wise food choices to stay ahead of your opponents.

The goal of Antimatter Matters is to collect the right elementary particles to assemble an atom. You have to avoid hazards like quantum entanglement, antimatter collisions, cosmic radiation and solar flares messing up your instruments—not to mention the actions of other player-scientists pursuing the same goal.

Along the way, you'll learn something about the strange and wonderful world of quantum physics: how a handful of elementary particles interact in various ways to form the nuclei and atoms that make up ourselves and everything we experience in the world around us.

item.description:
Impulse is a quick-playing 4X (explore, expand, exploit, and exterminate) game set in space with the game board being composed of cards that have actions on them. Players also have cards in hand, and in addition to featuring one of ten possible actions, these cards have a color (red, yellow, blue or green) and a size (1, 2 or 3, as indicated by the number of icons on the card). Each card also has six edges, and these edges connect adjacent cards in the hex-shaped playing area.

The cards in the playing area start face down, with each player controlling a card(their Home) on a corner of this area. Each player has two transport ships in the center of his Home card and a cruiser on an edge. Cruisers are used to patrol sectors of space and destroy opposing transports, while transports let you activate sectors that you enter.

On a turn, a player adds a card to the Impulse from his hand, then (optionally) performs an action for a tech in his playing area, then (optionally) performs all the actions in the Impulse, then draws two cards and adds them to his hand. The Impulse is a line of cards shared by all players that changes turn by turn as players add cards to it and as cards fall off once it reaches maximum size. Thus, players need to feed the Impulse with actions that benefit them more than opponents, but that's easier said than done.

When you perform actions – whether from moving transports to them or using the Impulse – you can boost them by having minerals of the same color or lots of transports. Each action has a single numeral on it, e.g., "Command [1] ship for one jump" or "Build [1] cruiser at home"; when you boost an action, you increase that numeral.

Players score points by destroying enemy ships (one point per ship), by controlling edge spaces on the central card (one point per edge), and by taking other actions via cards. The first player to score 20 points wins!

item.description:
A jig-saw puzzle game which can be played in four different ways.

Basic play: Each player gets a one of four different color/picture puzzle frames and a box of 36 numbered puzzle pieces of the same color. Then there is a die/dice/chit pull and the players take/loose pieces depending on version played. This continues till a player completes a puzzle and yells Eureko!

The four ways to play are:

1. Color Eureko! - roll color die (d6 yellow, brown, green, blue, yellow/blue, green/brown) and number die (d6 1, 2, 3, 4, -1, -2), get/loose that many pieces of the color(s) rolled.

2. Number Eureko! - Put your color puzzle pieces number side up (pieces are numbered from 1-72, not all numbers are in each puzzle), a number disc is drawn and any one with that number gets that piece, if the number was red players with that number also get a credit chit, chit may be turned in for more pieces.

3. Picture Eureko! - each player rolls the number die and gets/looses that many pieces.

4. Solitaire Eureko! - play however you want or just put the puzzles together.

The central computer's codes have been hacked and are circulating freely in the city. Batman is trying to recover them, but he is not alone... Who will take control of the city? As they move about the board, players must take different kinds of action. They must also face and outsmart villains like Clayface, Firefly and Mr. Freeze and attempt to avoid surprise explosions...

Aim of the Game: To recovers codes to obtain two coded keys and gain access to the Gotham City central computer to take control of it. The first player to do so wins.

Box contains: 
- 40 playing cards 
- 32 tokens(16 codes, 8 bombs, 8 coded keys) 
- 4 playing pieces (characters) 
- 2 dice (characters) 
- 1 six-figure die 
- Game rules 
- 20-sticker sheet

Pairadice Hockey is a hockey board game simulation that uses a pair of dice to activate results from a master game chart to recreate the game of hockey. Individual players are rated based on their actual season performance to generate reasonably accurate results over a full season worth of play. Many NHL and Minor League seasons are rated for play.

item.description:
AMERIKA takes place in an “alternate time-line” reality to explore the possibilities of what could have happened if certain events during the war had a much different result.

Players choose to either be Axis forces invading America, or Allied forces attempting to defend America long enough to achieve a technological edge and turn the tide of war.

The most unique part of AMERIKA is the ability of commanders to build their own custom invasion force. Following the army build rules, each side can customize their force to suit their own strategy. They also control how the forces are deployed at the start of the game. The balancing factor is a victory point time limit and a growing defensive force. The attackers must move fast!

The 20" X 30" map depicts the United States and surrounding areas as it was around WW2. Areas are broken up into Land Territories, City Zones, Nuclear Research Sites, and Naval Landing Zones. The Allies must defend their 20 major Cities from Axis occupation in order to continue fielding their defensive forces. However, they must also keep the enemy from capturing the 2 research facilities across the U.S. so atomic research can be harnessed and Victory Points earned. Axis forces are tasked with simultaneously cutting off Allied supplies and capturing nuclear technology for themselves to crush the last remaining opposition to Axis world domination. By attacking America from both sides at once, coordination and decisive action is a must!

AMERIKA also introduces veteran game players to a variety of new units like jet fighters and self-propelled anti-aircraft guns, while keeping each unit type’s rules easy enough for beginners to master. With just 8 unit types in the game, purchasing and combat move fast and are resolved simply using a battle board. All 8 unit-types are unique to this game and cannot be found elsewhere.

link.value: Amerika: Allied UFO – The YB-35 Flying Wing In Amerika
Amerika: Cruise Missile Attack – Surface Missiles In Amerika
Amerika: Defcon 1 – Atomic Defense in Amerika
Amerika: Ein Grosse Ratte – The P.1000 Ratte In Amerika
Amerika: Projekt Ursel Type XXI U-boat
Amerika: Taiho Kai – Great Phoenix of the Ocean
Amerika: Target Amerika – The Bomber Projects
Amerika: Thor's Hammer – The Karl Gerat Morser In Amerika

item.description:
Ein Schaf (also titled ã²ã¤ã˜ãŒã„ã£ã´ã, or Hitsuji ga Ippiki in Japanese) is a simple children’s card game.

The deck consists of cards with anywhere from one to seven sheep on them. Play proceeds with one player playing the “one”, the next player playing the “two”, and so on in order of rank. Players may at any time take a card from the deck and reset the count to one. Players must take a card if they do not have the correct card to play. The first player to get rid of his or her entire hand is the winner.

A funny game about telling a good story. But you have to fulfill a couple of requirements. First of all your story has a certain theme and then has to end with a specific punchline.
You have a stock of handcards where you choose your cartoon and punchline from, so it matches the theme.
When everyone told there story, you have to choose what story you liked best, second and third. 
And then there will be points for all the Players.

item.description:
In Relic Runners, each player takes on the role of a character keen to exploit and acquire relics that have been unearthed in a long lost part of the jungle. Each would-be archaeologist has a colorful past — retired university professor, former army captain, etc. — and wants to be the first to get their hands on the precious loot to earn the most victory points.

Players must navigate a series of paths in order to visit temples. The archaeologists are restricted in their movement by their access to rations, but thankfully they can place markers on paths to allow them to travel for free in future turns. The players also have a toolkit that can be upgraded in three particular ways to break the rules in some way or offer them an advantage as they move around.

Each time a player visits a temple, he takes a token. Initially the temples offer up victory points or some form of in-game bonus. When the final token is taken, a relic is placed there to be collected. The players earn large victory points for collecting relics of different types (set collection) and players can also earn bonus points for creating long routes and traveling along these to collect relics.

item.description:
A Card-Driven Action Strategy Game!

The planet Antaeras was a thriving world, full of majestic beauty and alive with a natural flow of magic that extended to all its inhabitants. This magic was its most precious commodity…but would also prove to be its downfall.

The ages-long civil war between the Brotherhood of Steam and the Reptilisaur Empire has now become a three-way battle with the appearance of the Corrupted Legion.

ARCANITE WARS is a strategy card game for two players where you must harvest resources, construct a base, train units, explore the terrain around you, and battle the enemy army. The player who destroys his opponent's Headquarters is victorious!

If you are familiar with the concepts behind the Real-Time Strategy game genre (think Command and Conquer, StarCraft, Age of Empires, etc), then you will easily pick up the flow of this game.

The Core Set comes complete with a set of Terrain cards and three races:

> The Brotherhood of Steam
> The Reptilisaur Empire
> The Corrupted Legion

Each of these races uses two decks: its Race deck (Units, buildings, and Workers) and Event deck (consisting of special abilities and ways to add to Units' strength on the battlefield). Each race has different strengths and plays differently from the others.

Everything you need to play is included - just grab another player and let the battle begin!

The Spider Lodge, a secret high council, is the ultimate ruler of Aar, the capital city of the savage world of Core. Through intrigues and skillful machinations, the members of the Spider Lodge influence the six Guilds of the city, which hold key positions in its community structure. They have developed a subtle method called "Equilibrium" in which they influence the actions of the Guilds for their own purposes without being exposed by doing so. Take the role of an esteemed member of the Spider Lodge and try through careful planning to achieve "Equilibrium", destroy the plans of your opponents and claim for yourself the title of the High Counselor of Aar.

In each round of Intrigue City each player changes the influence that he and one of his opponents has on the Guilds of Aar. Influence Tokens of three different values (1, 2 & 3) represent each player’s control over a Guild. Perfect balance of influence - not too obvious, nor too weak - is achieved by having Influence Tokens with a total value of six on a Guild; this is called an Equilibrium. At the end of each round each player scores Equilibrium Cards for every Equilibrium he has managed to maintain up to that point. During the game players vote to increase the power of each Guild, also increasing the point value of that Guild’s Equilibrium Cards, affecting each player’s final score.

item.description:
Erie Canal is a 2-4 player Print-and-Play game that focuses on transportation in the canal. The canal board pieces are modular so you can change the canal each time you play the game, offering many possible scenarios. As a part of the 2012 Historical Themed Board Game Contest, Erie Canal comes with 4 pre-defined scenarios to play.

In Erie canal each player on their turn will be given an allotment of action points, which they will use to perform various actions. Some of these actions will allow the player to control the locks, which is a new element introduced for this game. Each player will have to transport goods and people up and down the canal while trying to make effective use of these locks. The player gains the most victory points by transporting the most people and goods will be declared the winner.

Jak and Poi is a two-player card game based on the hand game Rock, Paper, Scissors.

Everybody knows that Rock beats Scissors which beats Paper which then beats Rock. But when we were kids, we all tried to go around this rule by inventing our own hand symbols like Lightning, Bomb or Tank. Jak and Poi builds on this “anything goes” concept and the result is an accessible one-card-per-turn game that has surprising depth and strategy.

The objective of the game is to reduce your opponent’s 20 life points to zero. To do this, each player uses the 2 main card types in the game: Jaks and Pois. The main mechanic of the game revolves around how these two card types interact with each other. Since Jaks (representing Rock, Paper, Scissors) can counter against or synergize with Pois (representing your lighting, bomb, tank, etc.) correctly anticipating your opponent’s moves or leading your opponent to play in your favor is key to victory.

While unique, the gameplay of Jak and Poi is only half the reason the game is so special. Leveraging on the fact that every one of us, at some point in our childhood, invented our own hand symbols to try and win at Rock, Paper, Scissors, we crowdsourced the creation of all the cards in the game from players and artists who wanted to let their imaginations run wild.

The two decks in Jak and Poi’s first release are the result of the efforts of 40+ designers and 20+ artists. This collaboration between passionate creators is no doubt the heart and driving force of the game.

BigforkOpoly is a promotional board game released by Pride Distributors, Inc. as a fundraiser for local community organizations in the town of Bigfork, Montana. It is a derivative of Monopoly and is virtually identical to it in most respects.

Ð—Ð°Ð¿Ñ€ÐµÑ‚Ð½Ñ‹Ðµ ÑÐ»Ð¾Ð²Ð° (No Words) is a game of (not-)creating words from the letters of the Russian alphabet. Each player has a hand of 3 cards (1 letter on each card). On his/her turn, the player should play one card from hand into the common pool. If after his/her turn any of the opponents is able to create a complete Russian word from the letters in the pool, the player has to take all the letters of this word as his penalty points (1 letter equals 1 penalty point). The winner is the player with lesser number of penalty points at the end of the game.

Contents:
84 cards with Cyrillic letters
rules

item.description:
It is the early 20th Century, and the great museums of Europe and America compete for artifacts from around the world in order to fill their museums with the most prestigious exhibitions. In Artifact, players are archaeologists researching sites around the globe to search for artifacts, which are then shipped back to the museums in order to produce exhibitions that increase funding for future digs and earn prestige to win the game. Actions and funds are limited, however, and competition is fierce. Sometimes it is even necessary to deal on the black market in order to generate extra income or to acquire the one artifact that will complete a valuable exhibition.

The player who earns the most prestige points through producing exhibitions and managing his budget best wins the game.

Artifact is a rich gaming experience that provides players with many options to think about. In order to make it easier to learn the game, the rules have been separated into the Base Game, followed by rules for the two expansions that, when added, make up the Complete Game. The game can be played and enjoyed as the base game or by including any one of the expansions, but the complete game is highly recommended for experienced players.

item.description:
1914, the world is on the brink of a major war. The major powers are preparing for the contest, but its resources for such an undertaking are very limited due to the social changes of recent times.
That's why the big companies charge each nation to find and acopien resources. Where where more then abound.
On Mars.
Who has the power in these resources will have much of the war won.



Descripción del Juego:
“Extraordinarios aparatos y máquinas maravillosas han permitido a los poderosos imperios europeos de principios del s. XX viajar hasta Marte. El descubrimiento del Unobtanium, metal de dureza imposible, en las profundidades del rocoso suelo marciano, han acrecentado las políticas militaristas entre las grandes potencias en los primeros meses de 1914.Representas a unas de las Compañías Mineras de los imperios, que agrupadas alrededor del Emporio Terrestre y compelidas por la guerra en ciernes, intentan establecer su dominio en el suelo marciano. 
Al final del juego triunfará aquella compañía que haya conseguido extraer más minerales y colonizar la mayoría de regiones marcianas.”

Mars Mineral War (1914) es un juego de mayorías, gestión de recursos y colocación de trabajadores, en el que los jugadores utilizan un mazo de cartas propio para gestionar las acciones. 
Las cartas representan los distintos “Contratos de Explotación” que el Emporio Terrestre ha concedido a las Compañías que intentan extraer el preciado Unobtanium. 
Cada jugador posee un mazo de 20 cartas (Contratos). Cada mazo tiene el mismo tipo de Contratos pero diferenciados por los Logos y el color de cada una de las Compañías. Así los jugadores gozan de las mismas oportunidades de jugar cada carta pero, dado que los mazos están mezclados y boca abajo, esas opciones se presentaran para cada uno de ellos en momentos distintos de la partida. Además, bajo ciertas condiciones, también podrán usar los Contratos de Explotación de las otras Compañías
Al principio de la partida los jugadores barajan su mazo y lo dejan boca abajo. Al finalizar la primera ronda deberán volver a mezclar su mazo de descartes y colocarlo, de nuevo, boca abajo. Los mazos que en la primera ronda eran idénticos, en la segunda ronda contienen cartas de los otros jugadores o descartes previos. 
Concretamente en su turno cada jugador toma cuatro cartas (Contratos de Explotación) de su mazo, elige una de ellas y la descarta boca arriba en un mazo de descartes propio, después escoge otra de las cartas de su mano y la pasa al jugador de su izquierda. 
Posteriormente los jugadores juegan o descartan, una a una, las tres cartas que quedan en su mano. 
 Los Contratos de Explotación (cartas) permiten explorar la superficie marciana o bien realizar distintas acciones:
i.- Realizar una o dos acciones sobre la Superficie del Planeta (iniciar explotaciones, ubicar trenes-oruga, reubicar minas, etc). 
ii.- Realizar una o dos acciones de Gestión y/o Explotación en el Tablero de Emporio (formar mineros en los barracones, extraer Unobtanium, vender el mineral, reasignar recursos, conseguir contenedores de energía de Oort).
iii. Descartase de dos cartas y obtener, a cambio, contenedores de energía o nuevos mineros formados de los barracones.
iv.-Descartarse de una carta y obtener, cada jugador, una unidad de energía.
Cada Contrato de Explotación ejecutado conlleva un gasto en energía. Además si el contrato originalmente pertenece a otra Compañía supondrá un gasto extra de energía. El mantenimiento de las instalaciones sobre la Superficie de Marte también genera un coste de energía.
El jugador con mayor número de puntos de victoria después del recuento de las dos rondas del juego será el ganador.

item.description:
Gladiators is a thematic combat game set in the sand arenas of the classic roman sport. Players each control 2 (in 2 player, 1 in 3-4 player) gladiators and simultaneously plot their actions upon their gladiator cards. Once three moves have been decided they are revealed and gladiators move around the arena attacking each other, hurling nets and trying to out manoeuvre their opponents.

Plays in 30-45 minutes, there is a mixture of luck and strategy in the outcome of the game.

Expert players are given further scenarios to try out which require adaptation of their existing tactics.

This is currently a print and play game that can be played with hex tiles and miniatures.

Kosmiczny Kupiec (Space Trader) is a economical board game where you get your own frigate handfull of credits and first transport assingment to complete. 
During the game you get random encounters like pirate attack,space police control or exploring some alien artifact. You can also upgrade your ship with either science, weapons or transport modules.
Goal of the game is to have the largest sum of money when the last assingment is completed.

Contents of the box:

Board
 23 trading missions cards
 23 space routes cards
 23 exploration cards
 36 goods tokens
 4 spaceship boards
 8 science module upgrades
 8 weapon module upgrades
 24 transport module upgrades
 Space cash supply
 Dice
 4 pawns to represent ships
 Rules of play

From directions:

The box represents the mining fields of the Klondike.
Put the nuggets into the lower part of the box through any of the mine openings and place the mine covers on at random.
The players decide which shall commence the game and also the number of ounces of gold to be found to constitute the game as 50 ounces, 100 ounces, 200 ounces, etc.
Shake the nuggets in the box.
The first player takes a "pick axe" and lifts up any mine cover he chooses. If a nugget appears underneath lying wholly or partly within the circle covered by the mine cover, the player has to his credit the number of ounces stamped on the underside of the mine cover and he
also has another chance to lift a cover and so continue until he finds a mine with no nugget, at which time he looses his play. 
The second player to the left follows and so on throughout the game.
If more than one nugget is found at one time under a mine cover the player places to his credit as many ounces of gold as there are nuggets times the mark on the cover.
Leave all the nuggets in the box and shake them up between every play. Any player can shake when another player is not actually lifting up a mine cover.
The player which first gets the number of ounces of gold agreed upon at the beginning of the game, wins.
Implements:
6 mine covers, 6 nuggets, 1 pick axe.

name.value: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles ‘Turtle Power' Trading Card Game

item.description: Panini are proud to announce the launch of their exciting new trading card game based on the legendary cartoon from Nickelodeon; Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. The franchise is back with a brand new look and awesome new content and Panini's all-new trading card game will draw on this and is sure to be a huge hit with Turtles fans. Featuring all of the lead characters, the collection will follow the Turtles as they fight to clean up the streets of New York and defend innocent citizens from Shredder and The Kraang. The collection will boast a host of fantastic trading cards, limited edition cards, collector's binder and game board for collectors to play and trade with each other.

name.value: Hand in Hand: The Card Game

item.description:
Hand in Hand is a deck of 60 cards, each with two different brightly coloured halves that depict one half of a child that needs your help to be made whole. Similar to a deck of playing cards, there’s no limit to how many ways you can play with these cards.

However, the base game is suitable for 2-6 players aged 6+ and can be played in 15-20 minutes. By matching colours, players create a chain of children holding hands that can be “taken home” to score points. This is a great family game that offers positive, encouraging turns leaving everyone feeling like they’ve contributed to something good.

Race to collect and successfully sacrifice the most princesses to the wise Dryer Dragon in order to prevent the asocalypse and be named king or queen of Lint. Your sock puppet adventurer has been chosen to overthrow the evil princess cult in their effort to raise the destroyer of Lint existence, TOES. The only way to prevent the end of days is to successfully sacrifice the required amount of the evil princesses so the Dryer Dragon can craft the great TOE SOCK OF BINDING to defeat TOES, but if too many princesses are rejected then TOES will arise and the evil princesses will win.

Players win by being the first to fill their "throne meter" - accomplished by sacrificing princesses. (description from Kickstarter)

Game description from the publisher:

Raid the world of myth and legend! Crush every foe you meet. Backstab your friends and steal their stuff. Grab the treasure and run.

Munchkin Legends is the new Munchkin card game about legendary adventure...with none of that stupid roleplaying stuff. You'll defeat mythic monsters and grab fabled magic items! Don the Death Mask and Achilles' Heels. Wield Thor's Hammer...or maybe the Magic Bassoon. Start by slaughtering the Heebie-Jeebies and Johnny Zucchiniseed, and work your way up to the Kraken...

link.value: Munchkin Sparkly Good Fairy Shot Glass

item.description:
The purpose of this game is to dispel commonly held myths related to teen pregnancy and sexuality and to show the consequences for one's quality of life. In the process of playing, teenagers will be challenged to face the real consequences of sex.

While moving around the board, players will draw cards dealing with the subjects of Sex Facts, Health and Disease, Contraceptives, Sex and Values, and Sex and Success. Correctly answering the questions on these cards gives the player points.

Certain spaces on the board will force the player to spin the Sex Wheel of Fortune. Of the several results on the spinner, one is pregnancy. Some spaces also will cause a pregnancy. Failure to maintain your score above a certain point will also result in pregnancy.

Pregnancy forces players into a Dilemma. Female players will have to decide on which path to take: Adoption, Motherhood, or Abortion. Male players will have to decide on which path to take: Support or Marriage. Each choice may have different consequences affecting a player's score.

After a predetermined period of gameplay, players will tally their scores. The player(s) with the higher scores have increased their chances of success and happiness while those with lower scores have diminished their chances.

Dr. Boom is a 2-5 player variant of Two Rooms and a Boom, which requires at least six players. Dr. Boom is a wallet-sized, take-with-you-anywhere game of social deduction. One player is the President who needs to let the real Doctor into his/her office. Careful! If the President chooses the nefarious Dr. Boom, the end result is explosive failure.

item.description:
From the Publisher's Website:

'QBits' is a new innovative mathematical board game designed by young people for young people. It incorporates the four basic principles of maths (addition, subtraction, multiplication and division) in a format that is quick and easy for players of all ages and abilities to learn. Without even realising it, players are continually doing maths in a fun way throughout the game. Younger or less able players can play using smaller numbers whilst older or more able players can play using higher numbers, once familiar with the rules this becomes a tactical game which even teaches prime numbers.

Game Includes:
Game Board
50 Numbered Plastic "Qubes"
Cloth Holding Bag
Score Pad
Pencil

Supernova is a 36 card space battle game published in six installments of the 2000 AD comic. Players take turns dealing a card from the top of their and selecting one of the parameters listed on the card, such as Attack Armament, Crew, etc. The opposing player then plays the top card from their deck and compares the ratings of the chosen parameter. The highest rating wins that contest. The Supernova ship beats all others. The player to collect all the cards wins.

Battle through space to match up the THUNDERCATS characters!
Match and collect complete characters to win the game.

Spin the wheel in center of the board and place a characters body part (either their head, body or legs) in corresponding section of the board. 
Player with most correctly matched complete characters is the winner!

A game for 6 players. 4 years and over.

Doodle Jump transforms the app of the same name into a board game, with players needing to push their Doodler to the top of the board faster than anyone else. To do this, you'll need to use the dice well and take risks during play. The first player to reach the top level of the board wins!

On your turn, you roll six dice – five standard d6 dice and one symbol die – then use either the symbol on that special die or the sum of one or more numbers to jump your Doodler to an open pad that's horizontally adjacent or close overhead on the next level. (Each pad has a number on it, and to jump to a pad, you need dice that sum to that number.) If you fail to do this, you fall straight down to the highest unoccupied pad – which might take you all the way to the bottom of the game board! The symbols on the dice let you slide a row left or right one space, reroll your other dice, or move an unoccupied level to the top of the game board (effectively pushing players down). If you do jump or use a symbol, you can reroll the remaining dice to try to move again or you can stop where you are.

If you land on another Doodler, that player falls straight down. If you land on a power tile (which are not recommended for the first game), you acquire a propeller hat, shield, jetpack or jump shoes to use on a later turn; flip over a trampoline or springs, and you jump again immediately. Doodle Jump also includes monster, UFO and black hole power tiles for expert play.

item.description:
Alchemy dice is a strategic dice allocation/worker placement game in which the players will use their dice to collect precious stones as resources for their alchemical studies, increase their influence by buying new cards and dice and finally earn victory points to win the game.


 
 
 


"The Patriarch of Rishadan was an impressive man who had used his secret knowledge to prolong his life well beyond his natural span. But in the end even he could not escape the last voyage and now the alchemist guild is without a leader. 
A council of 111 alchemists has chosen the few who are deemed worthy enough to become the new patriarch and the most powerful man in the whole city. But which one is the best? Which one knows the secrets of the transmutation like no other? Which one can use his influence in the city best to strengthen his position? And which one will be triumphant in the secret rituals known as “chucking the dice”?
Let the competition begin and the council will elect the most successful alchemist as the new patriarch."


 
 
 


In Alchemy Dice, the player start out with three different cards, three dice, an unique Character and an unique assortment of resources. During each round the players are rolling their dice and allocate them to their cards where they, based on the dice-roll will be able to use different actions - like collecting resources, modifying another die, tranforming one kind of resource into another one and so on.
During the later phases of the game each player can use the collected resources to buy a new card and/or die which will improve his abilities during future rounds.

The game can end in several ways (e.g. if all dice from 2 of the 4 dice markets have been bought, the last card from the deck has been drawn or one player has bought 8 cards) and the player with the most victory points (granted by the cards and through bonus conditions) wins the game.


 
 
 


Currently there are 2 versions of the game which will both be available through the Gamecrafter later this year:

The Deluxe version:
This version includes all the cards and all the other components needed to play the game. The resource tokens are glass beads and the game comes with cloth bags to store all the dice and gems for a high production quality version of the game.

Included in the deluxe version are:
- 56 cards
- 48 dice
- 60 gems
- 40 markers
- 4 cloth bags
- 1 start player marker
- 1 rulebook

The Redux version:
This is the version for the gamer on a small budget but with plenty of spare parts at home. The redux version comes in a small tuck-box and contains only the 56 cards and the rules. In order to play with this version who will have to provide your own dice, gems and markers. But as most people will have these things at hand already the redux version offers a very affordable way to get Alchemy Dice.

Octonauts: Fische retten is an easy roll and move game for children.

According to the result of a die roll, you can move a fish on the bord. 
The first player to reach his boarder areas with four fishes is the winner.

item.description:
Introduction

Kopano is a drawless connection game for two players: Black and White. It’s played on the intersections (points) of a square board, which is initially empty. The top and bottom edges of the board are colored black; the left and right edges are colored white. "Kopano" is the Tswana word for "connection".

				
					Definitions

Two like-colored stones are strongly connected if they are orthogonally adjacent to each other, and weakly connected if they are diagonally adjacent to each other without sharing any strongly connected neighbor. Note that two stones of different colors are never considered to be connected.

A chain is a set of (weakly or strongly) connected stones.

				
					Play

Starting with Black, the players take turns placing stones of their own color on empty points of the board, one stone per turn.

It's illegal to place a stone on a point where it makes a weak connection unless placing an enemy stone on that same point would also make a weak connection. It's also illegal to form a crosscut, i.e. a 2x2 pattern of stones consisting of two diagonally adjacent Black stones and two diagonally adjacent White stones.

If a player can't make a move on his turn, he must pass. Passing is otherwise not allowed. There will always be a move available to at least one of the players.

The game is won by the player who completes a chain of his color touching the two opposite board edges of his color. Draws are not possible.

				
					Pie rule

The pie rule is used in order to make the game fair. This means that White will have the option, on his first turn only, to change sides instead of making a regular move.

item.description:
Welcome to the Rococo era during the reign of Louis XV when it's safe to say that holding lavish balls is quite trendy. Important personalities wrap up in noble coats and dresses, anxious to outshine one another. As the biggest event is coming up in just a few weeks, everyone is turning to you with their requests: an elegant coat here, a stunning dress there, or a donation to fund the fireworks at the event. Soon you realize that it's not just about your dressmaking business anymore – it's about managing the most prestigous ball of the era...and now it's time to ro(c)k!

Rokoko is a Eurostyle board game with an interesting take on deck-building. Each turn you play one of your employee cards and let that employee perform a task: hire a new employee, buy resources, manufacture a coat or dress, or invest in the ball's decorations. But not every employee is up to every task, so you must choose and lead your employees wisely – especially since each employee grants a unique bonus and some of these bonuses generate prestige points.

After seven rounds, the game ends with the big ball and a final scoring. Then you gain prestige points for certain employee bonuses and for coats and dresses that you rent out to guests at the ball as well as for decorations that you funded. The player who collected the most prestige points wins.

item.description:
Working in a toy factory is enjoyable, but it's also a very demanding job! What happens if an automated toy machine breaks down? Who will bring order to the mess that is created?

In Mess Machine, the players are workers in a toy factory where a machine has malfunctioned and is messing up the production. They must cooperate and figure out quickly the correct buttons to press in order to repair the damage and reassemble the toys! However, only one player will win. Can you find the best way to fix the broken toy and get the other players to follow your way?

item.description: A card/dice game relying heavily on chance as players try to steal money away from Dicken's Ebenezer Scrooge. Players take the role of a famous character, Mr Pickwick, Artful Dodger, Fagin, Mr. Micawber or Oliver Twist. By rolling a lettered die and numbered die, you determine if you collect or deposit money with Scrooge, and sometimes you draw one of the lavishly illustrated cards (with artwork from Habiot Browne, George Cattermole, Robert Seymore, George Cruikshank and John Leech) which forces you to pay extra fees or gather extra gains. The game was designed with the aid of the curator of the Dickens House Museum.

Players command a squadron of tanks, German or Soviet, battling in Eastern Europe. Unit cards display the capabilities of each tank unit, and players mark their orders on their unit cards simultaneously and in secret.

Game components include six 1/100 tank models, four double-sided gameboards, terrain tiles, game cards, player aids, ten dice and two water-based markers.

item.description:
This is an educational game based on French animated television series which tells the story of the human body for children.

Aim of the game is simple: you have to complete as soon as possible coins with the image of Hemo. To do this you must correctly answer questions, defend against virus attacks,
use of the opportunities offered by the field "Opportunity" and
not to give up when you hit the field "Unfortunate".

link.value: Once Upon a Time (based on animated series)

item.description:
Races of the Expanse is a game of creating an alien race, or human variant race by shuffling multiple decks of cards together, and then using your race to explore and colonize the Expanse of space between the Orion Spur and the Sagitarius arm. We plan to bring the game to Kickstarter this Fall. In Races of the Expanse each player takes turns picking a deck for their base creature, such as Crystaline, Humanoid, Crustacians, or Octopoids, Then in reverse order players choose a special ability Deck from clairvoyant, aquatic, subterranean, or creative. Your random homeworld will then add a regional events deck. These three decks will be Shuffled together, to form your races play deck. Extra races and abilities are planned as stretch goals. finally a communal planets deck is built based on the number of players. Play proceeds clockwise from a random start player.
 All players start with a hand of five cards. Player 1 plays up to two cards, and then draws two cards, unless affected by cards or special abilities. Players may have no more than 10 cards in their hand. If, after drawing, you have more than ten cards, discard until you have only ten. If a player runs out of cards in their deck they shuffle their discarded cards and start the deck fresh. Play moves clockwise until the last planet is drawn. (Planets can only be drawn when Explorers are played.) When the last planet is drawn, each player gets one last turn, and then the game is ended and a winner is decided.
 The player with the most resource at the end of the game is the winner. You get resource by having the most population on a planet. If two or more players have an equal amount of population on a planet, nobody gets the resource for that planet. The max population of a planet is in the upper lefthand corner of the planet card, the resource of that planet is in the lower righthand corner of the planet card.

Help Wanted is an adult party game in which players compete against each other to see who can provide the best solution for another player’s problem. Help Wanted includes a lot of different problems to solve ranging from the ridiculous to the apocalyptic. To solve these problems, players will have over 400 different solution cards, for a grand total of over 500 cards. Add in the human elements of interpretation and presentation and the possibilities are infinite!

With similar party games you find yourself playing one artless card, face down, in secret while a judge chooses their favorite and leaves you wondering about their logic when your card was (clearly) the best choice. You find yourself arguing your point and explaining that everyone else is (clearly) dumb, but the decision has already been made. Bummer!

With Help Wanted you still want the judge to choose you, but you have the opportunity to weave together a short narrative to state your case by combining up to three different Solution Cards and wooing the judge with your keen intellect.
